facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated September 9, 1966 of Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 885 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 9, 1966 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 885 of 1964. P. Rao and S. N. Prasad and B. D. Sharma, for the appellant.

facts.text: First respondent was a combatant Clerk in the Indian Army for more than 14 years.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent was a companybatant Clerk in the Indian Army for a period of more than 14 years. He was discharged from that post on 9th June, 1953.

facts.text: First respondent was discharged from Army post on 9th June 1953.

anchor.surface_text: He was discharged from that post on 9th June, 1953. On 2nd July 1953, he was re-employed as an ordinary clerk on the pay scale of Rs. 55- 85EB-4-125-5-130.

facts.text: First respondent re-employed as ordinary clerk on 2nd July 1953 on pay scale Rs. 55-85EB-4-125-5-130.

anchor.surface_text: On 2nd July 1953, he was re-employed as an ordinary clerk on the pay scale of Rs. 55- 85EB-4-125-5-130. His pay was re-fixed in the above scale at Rs. 70/- plus a personal pay of Rs. 2.50 by an Order dated 28th October, 1958,

facts.text: Pay of first respondent re-fixed at Rs. 70 plus personal pay Rs. 2.50 by order dated 28th October 1958 with effect from 2-7-1953.

anchor.surface_text: His pay was re-fixed in the above scale at Rs. 70/- plus a personal pay of Rs. 2.50 by an Order dated 28th October, 1958, with effect from the date of re- employment, i.e., 2-7-1953.

facts.text: Government of India, Ministry of Defence issued Office Memorandum No. 2 54 58/5801/D Civil on 15th July 1960 providing benefits to ex-military personnel on re-employment.

anchor.surface_text: On 15th July, 1960, the Government of India, Ministry of Defence, issued a general Order called Office Memorandum No. 2 54 58/5801/D Civil  providing for certain benefits to ex-military personnel on re-employment on the basis of their length of actual military service.

facts.text: Office Memorandum provides for adding increments equal to completed years of military service to bottom of scale for re-employed ex-military.

anchor.surface_text: The general effect of that Order was that those who are entitled to its benefits, would get fixed in the scale applicable to them by adding to the bottom of their scales increments equal to the total number of companypleted years of military service.

facts.text: Office Memorandum applies to re-employments on or after 25-11-1958; past cases not to be reopened.

anchor.surface_text: These orders will apply to all cases of reemployment occurring on or after 25-11-58 and past cases will number be reopened.

facts.text: Exception in OM for pensioners in service on date of issue, re-employed prior to 25-11-1958 for unspecified period or extending beyond, subject to option.

anchor.surface_text: In the cases of pensioners who are in service on the date of issue of these orders and have been re-employed from a date prior to 25-11-1958 for an unspecified period or for a period which extends beyond the date of issue of the present orders may, subject to their option, be brought under the provisions of these orders with immediate effect.

facts.text: Option to be exercised in writing within three months from date of issue of OM; once exercised final.

anchor.surface_text: 4 . The option should be exercised in writing within a period of three months from the date of issue of these orders. The option once exercised shall be final.

facts.text: First respondent filed Writ Petition No. 885 of 1964 in Mysore High Court.

anchor.surface_text: passed by the High Court of Mysore in a Writ Petition filed by the first respondent.

facts.text: Mysore High Court allowed writ petition and directed respondent No. 2 to refix pay of respondent No. 1 at Rs. 89/- as from 2-7-1953 with consequential adjustments.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court allowed the writ petition and issued an order directing respondent No. 2 to refix the pay of respondent No. 1 in the scale of pay of Rs. 55-3-85-EB-4-125-130 at 89/- as from 2-7-1953 and to make companysequential adjustments and payments.

facts.text: First respondent was re-employed before 25-11-1958.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 clearly does number companye within this category. The Order then goes on to say that past cases will number be re-opened.

facts.text: There is no dispute that first respondent exercised the option under the Order.

facts.text: Supreme Court held first respondent entitled to benefit of the Order.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, think that the High Court was right in its view that the first respondent was entitled to the benefit of the Order.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 9, 1966 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 885 of 1964.
This is an appeal by Special Leave from the order dated the 9th of September, 1966 passed by the High Court of Mysore in a Writ Petition filed by the first respondent.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 9, 1966 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 885 of 1964. P. Rao and S. N. Prasad and B. D. Sharma, for the appellant.
passed by the High Court of Mysore in a Writ Petition filed by the first respondent. The first respondent was a combatant Clerk in the Indian Army for a period of more than 14 years.

issues.text: Whether the Order was applicable to the first respondent who was re-employed before 25-11-1958 such that his past case could be reopened upon exercising the option under paragraph 3

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contended before us that the Order was not applicable to the first respondent, as he was re-employed before 25-11-1958 and his pay had already been fixed after re-employment and therefore according to the terms of the Order the case of the 1st respondent, being a past one, could not be reopened. To resolve this question, it is necessary to understand the provisions of the Order.

issues.text: Whether the administrative Order conferred a justiciable right upon the first respondent enforceable in a court by a writ or order in the nature of mandamus

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, however, contended that the Order being an administrative direction conferred no justiciable right upon the first respondent which could be enforced in a Court by a writ or order in the nature of mandamus. The appellant submitted that the very foundation for the issue of a writ or an order in the nature of mandamus is the existence of a legal right and as an administrative order could confer no justiciable right, the High Court was wrong in issuing the order directing the second respondent to fix the pay of the first respondent in accordance with the Order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Administrative orders can confer justiciable rights forming part of service conditions where govt supplements rules under Art.309 (Sant Ram Sharma); enforceable like schemes in Indo Afghan Agencies; specific Order created such right.

holdings.text: The Order is not retrospective in character; pay to be fixed with effect from the date of the Order (15th July 1960), not from date of re-employment (2-7-1953).

anchor.surface_text: It was contended on behalf of the appellant that the Order not being retrospective in character, the respondents pay should not have been fixed with retrospective effect from 2- 7-1953. The Order is not retrospective in character. The High Court was therefore wrong in fixing the pay with retrospective effect from 2-7-1953. The direction could only be to fix the pay with effect from the date of the Order and the first respondent did not contend otherwise in this Court.

holdings.text: Generally speaking, an administrative order confers no justiciable right, but this rule is subject to exceptions; govt can issue supplementary instructions under Art.309 governing service conditions if rules silent.

anchor.surface_text: Generally speaking, an administrative Order confers no justiciable right, but this rule, like all other general rules, is subject to exceptions. This Court has held in Sant Ram Sharma v. State of Rajasthan and Another that although Government cannot supersede statutory rules by administrative instructions, yet, if the rules framed under Art. 309 of the Constitution are silent on any particular point, the Government can fill up gaps and supplement the rules and issue instructions not inconsistent with the rules already framed and these instructions will govern the conditions of service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of precedents (Sant Ram Sharma); qualified general rule with exceptions.

holdings.text: Administrative schemes like Import Trade Policy can be enforced by courts in appropriate cases; administrative orders can confer rights and impose duties.

anchor.surface_text: In Union of India and Others v. M s. Indo Afghan Agencies Ltd., this Court, in considering the nature of the Import Trade Policy said Granting that it is executive in character, this Court has held that Courts have the power in appropriate cases to compel performance of the obligations imposed by the Schemes upon the departmental authorities. To say that an administrative order can never confer any right would be too wide a proposition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent analogy from Indo Afghan Agencies.

anchor.surface_text: It was contended on behalf of the appellant that the Order not being retrospective in character, the respondents pay should not have been fixed with retrospective effect from 2- 7-1953. The Order is not retrospective in character. The High Court was therefore wrong in fixing the pay with retrospective effect from 2-7-1953. The direction could only be to fix the pay with effect from the date of the Order and the first respondent did not contend otherwise in this Court.
